poll_list.title: Dai Foundation Board Member Election Poll - December 12, 2022

discourse_list.title: Candidates for Dai Foundation Board Member Election Poll

content.content: With the onboarding of the Dai Foundation Core Unit, Dai Foundation committed to include members appointed by MakerDAO on its board. To honor this we posted a Call for interest in becoming a Dai Foundation board member earlier this year. Following the call, two candidates are now ready to seek election for this role by Maker Governance. The two candidates are @Daimon-Law and @0xbocaJ, and their candidacy statements are included further down in this post. With the recently approved budget for Dai Foundation there is funding for adding one Maker Governance appointed member to the Dai Foundation board. After consultation with @prose11 and @Patrick_J I therefore ask GovAlpha for a ratification poll to be posted in this governance cycle, where MKR voters have the option to vote for one of the candidates or vote for appointing none of the candidates at this time. The election process is currently not governed by a MIP, so the appointment will be limited to a two year period with the option of re-appointment. The appointed member will be asked to take lead on creating a MIP that can govern the election process in the future. The candidate statements follow (in the order I received them from the candidates). See the candidate statement for @Daimon-Law.  See the candidate statement for @0xbocaJ. Now is the time for Maker Governance including @Recognized-Delegates to ask the candidates relevant questions on how they intend to act as a Maker Governance appointed board member to the Dai Foundation.  Candidate statement for @Daimon-Law   Introduction and platform Paul Imseih Key Info Forum: @Daimon-Law Github: https://github.com/Daimon-Law Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/in/pimseih/ Resides in the UTC+10 time zone (Australia).  Core Values High Ethical Standards – I believe this is essential in all walks of life and absolutely critical for not-for-profit organisations such as the Dai Foundation. This includes having systems and policies in place to support ethical decision making and good governance. Custodian and Ambassador – The Dai Foundation has, as its primary focus, guarding the interests of the Maker DAO ecosystem and its intellectual property. I’m a very strong believer in the idea that leadership roles require a higher responsibility when representing Maker DAO in public and protecting its interests. Getting the Details Right – Having good intentions is a great start but this counts for nothing without solid execution. I like to see things done well and done right.  Background Firstly, thank you to the Dai Foundation and the MakerDAO community for considering me for the role of Dai Foundation Board member. Before I present my platform, I should probably introduce myself. I have been an Australian and UK lawyer for over 25 years, working mainly in the technology and intellectual property space. I’d majored in pure and applied mathematics at University so it seemed natural to work at the intersection of technology and law. My previous roles involved a lot of time working in Asia Pacific and Europe on some of the biggest technology deals going around at the time ($500m and upwards). I’ve held senior leadership roles and have managed teams as well. My introduction to crypto was in 2016, buying a small amount of BTC from a Bitcoin ATM at the back of a very sketchy bottle shop. I got home, starting at the BTC on the Bread app and had to read everything I could find about the visionaries, the technology and the industry. I was hooked. Within months I was attending and then moderating weekly crypto meetups and online crypto forums. Community was always key to this. There has always been a legal angle to the crypto story. The major themes that stimulate me as a lawyer and jurist are pretty simple to explain but insanely difficult to solve: how can we capture the transformative power of this technology as it applies to the law? And on the flipside: how should the law respond to this emerging tech? At the beginning of 2020, I resigned from my in-house legal role and went all-in, launching my own law firm – Daimon Legal. It’s a growing firm supporting start-ups in the crypto and Web3 space. I’m also active with the LexDAO initiative and help guide projects across the industry.  Platform Statement I have been a huge fan of the MakerDAO community for some time – it has one of the broadest range of opinions and stakeholders, yet still manages to achieve extraordinary success. I know most of the folks here want to make a positive difference to the state of banking and finance, improve access to financial products and services and lower the barriers to entry to global commerce. What’s more, we can do this in energy-efficient ways that reduces reliance on trusted intermediaries and bureaucracy. MakerDAO is at the forefront of this ambitious task. Here is my understanding of the core objectives of the Dai Foundation and how I plan to contribute to each one:   Identify and protect MakerDAO’s intellectual property: With 25 years’ experience handling and managing intellectual property in the technology sector, I feel that I have the right skill-set to support this objective. I’ve reviewed, drafted and negotiated hundreds of IP agreements and developed IP policies in the public and private sector. In more recent years, I’ve made contributions to Web3 intellectual property development, particularly around NFTs (see my Github page for examples). There is still a lot to do here. ·Formulate ethics policies and board governance procedures: as in-house legal counsel, I’ve been the custodian and author of multiple policy documents including anti-bribery/anti-corruption policies and Codes of Conduct. I’ve also prepared risk management guidelines and risk escalation procedures and held management seats in risk escalation and crisis response teams so I’m well versed in the handling of complex scenarios involving op-sec, technology, public relations and related legal issues. I’ve also been a board member and company secretary which will help with some of the day-to-day functioning of the Foundation.  Participate in education and outreach: While I’ve run training and education sessions for many years,  I’ve been heavily involved in community forum management and outreach in the crypto space through the weekly meetups and forum moderation. I’m also a deal lawyer by training so I’m looking forward to helping the Foundation with any negotiations they might get involved with.  Fiduciary Obligations of the Foundation: I have read and noted the Foundation’s governing Trust Deed and recognise the fiduciary duties associated with the role. The Foundation has been established in its present form to secure its longevity and independence and I will endeavour to uphold that objective.  Time commitment: This is, provisionally, a 2-year appointment. I have committed to the Board that I can fulfill the entirety of that term, if elected.  Conflict of Interest Statement I hold a diversified range of cryptocurrencies across the top 20 digital assets (by market cap) as well a number of tokens in low-cap projects. I also hold a very small portfolio of Australian stocks. My primary income is from my work outside of MakerDAO. I do not receive outside compensation for anything involving Maker DAO or the Dai Foundation. If voted on by the community and appointed to the role, I will remain mindful of actual or perceived conflicts of interest during the tenure. Any conflicts of interest that I become aware of will be raised with the Dai Foundation and appropriate steps will be taken to mitigate the potential for further conflict. Final Comments Having seen both sides of the dotcom crash and the GFC, I learnt early on that market cycles don’t slow innovation. If anything, they inspire it. We are entering a period where the work of the MakerDAO community and the Dai Foundation is only going to increase. As the regulatory environment matures, MakerDAO and the Dai Foundation will face challenges requiring a thoughtful response and some savvy planning. Some of this work is already underway and I am ready to contribute to these efforts where I can. If you have any questions, please don’t hesitate to message me here on the MakerDAO forum @Daimon-Law  Candidate statement for @0xbocaJ  Candidate Information:  Name: Jacob Minne LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/jacob-minne-997655b Twitter:  https://twitter.com/jacob_minne Publications and Additional information: https://www.morganlewis.com/bios/jminne  Candidate Statement: Thank you for this opportunity to apply for a position as a Dai Foundation board member.  Since 2012, I have been a blockchain enthusiast, mining bitcoin from my apartment—and learning hard lessons about custody, courtesy of Mt Gox—while following the ongoing legal and policy debates around digital assets and working to build this interest into my professional law practice. I believe this interest, coupled with my near decade of experience in US intellectual property law and experience with nonprofits, dovetails with the Dai Foundation’s mandate to safeguard the intellectual property of the Maker Community and makes me an ideal choice for the board member position.  Below, I have shared further details on my interest and experience, including my background in IP and blockchain law, commitment to volunteerism and nonprofit service, and my interest in the Dai Foundation. Legal Experience My professional interests have long focused on the intersection of law, technology, and society, and for many years, my career focused on IP counseling and litigation kept me engaged with that point of interest.  I have worked with well over a hundred clients on a variety of IP and technology matters, including multiyear patent, copyright and trade secret litigation, trademark counseling, portfolio development and monitoring, due diligence for mergers and acquisitions, and IP licensing. Some notable matters include:  From 2013 to 2021, through trial, two appeals and a denied petition to the US Supreme Court, representation of a US nonprofit, in its lengthy patent litigation, eventually helping secure over $300 million in damages for willful infringement of the nonprofit’s lifechanging biotechnology patents. In 2019, I provided _pro bono _copyright counseling for an Oakland, California game development nonprofit that promoted opportunities for low-income youth and youth of color to develop video game projects, helping ensure these children are equipped to thrive and succeed in any field they choose, including the tech and video game industries. In 2020, I provided counseling for a NFT marketplace, including developing a framework for on-chain recording of post-sale royalty obligations.  In another matter, I worked with our tax group to analyze tax implications related to an NFT minting and issuance by a 501(c)(4) nonprofit.  Since 2017, as my firm, Morgan Lewis, took on an increasing amount of blockchain work, I have had numerous opportunities to work across practice groups.  As part of this, I have studied relevant regulations related to US securities law, CFTC practices, and money transmitter and “bitlicense” regulation.  In July of this year, I was formally extended and took an invitation to switch practice groups from Intellectual Property to Investment Management so that I could focus full-time on blockchain related matters. Commitment To Nonprofit Service Service to nonprofit organizations has been personally important to me for many years.  During my undergraduate studies, I helped found a local Students for a Free Tibet chapter at the University of Puget Sound, serving four years as treasurer.  In law school, I continued my commitment to community service. Most relevant to this application, I served on the editorial board of the Santa Clara High Technology Law Journal. Since joining Morgan Lewis, I have focused on using my legal expertise to give back to the community.  In addition to the matters discussed above, I have devoted over 60 hours each year to pro bono matters, including a successful 2016 application for presidential clemency for a pro bono client who was sentenced to life in prison for drug crimes committed while he was a minor, and representation of ICE detainees applying for extraordinary bail to secure release from facilities with active COVID-19 outbreaks.  I consider this opportunity for service on the Dai Foundation board a continuation of a decade’s long commitment to service in my community. Interest in Maker and the Dai Foundation My professional work recently afforded me an opportunity to take a deep dive into the Maker community and I was impressed with what I found.  While Maker’s ambitions of creating a truly decentralized digital currency seemed like a Herculean task, the community was making real progress with buy in from both DeFi and TradFi institutions.  On top of that, governance power had in many ways been devolved to the community, without stripping the community of key assets and leaving it an empty husk.  The community discussion touched on a range of issues I was personally interested in, and I have been active in the forms and discord ever since. The Dai Foundation is of particular interest, and I am drawn towards the Foundation’s commitment to supporting the vision of MakerDAO—what the Dai Foundation’s Trust Deed describes as “a decentralized, autonomous, open, accessible and price stable payment system and a financial infrastructure based on blockchain technology”—through use of the MakerDAO intangible assets to promote “sustainable growth of the MakerDAO system and maximizing the public good thereof.”  I know personally how life changing execution of this vision could be for millions of people who, though accident of their birth, are locked out of the world community’s financial system, and face exorbitant fees or capricious denial of service for financial autonomy many of us take for granted. If elected, I look forward to continuing the excellent work the Dai Foundation is already doing to ensure that Maker’s IP is effectively and efficiently accounted for.  I hope to engage with the community to explain some of the nuances that can come up with this process and to gradually streamline the process further.  I also hope to be a resource for the Dai Foundation and the community when complex IP challenges or questions arise. Disclosures and Potential Conflicts All statements by me on this form, Discord, Twitter, LinkedIn, and elsewhere regarding this application are my own, and not my client’s or Morgan Lewis’.  Likewise, I would serve as a board member in my personal and individual capacity only, not acting as a lawyer or employee of Morgan Lewis. I own several digital assets, including Dai and other stablecoins, and may purchase other digital assets of any type in the future. I am outside counsel for a number of blockchain and digital asset related clients including Redwood Trust, Inc.  In the event I am elected and I become aware of any representation adverse to Maker or the Dai Foundation, I will, where ethically permitted to do so, disclose the representation and screen myself from further work on that matter. – Thank you again for consideration of my application, and I look forward to engaging with the community and answering any questions you might have.

You both seem like great candidates for the position. As each of you are in private practice, do either of you foresee material conflicts from former, current or future clients, and if so, what will be your framework for analyzing the possibility of a conflict waiver and who to represent? I think this is a particularly acute issue for @0xbocaJ, as Morgan Lewis is a massive firm with numerous clients that could present conflicts, and he will have little to no say over client intake and conflict waiver/representation decisions as an Associate.

Thanks for the great question. I can confirm there are no material conflicts for my firm. We don’t handle litigious matters at all so the likelihood of client conflict with MakerDAO or the Dai Foundation in the future will be extremely low. Where there’s an opportunity for collaboration between any of my clients and the Foundation, I obviously don’t want to be caught picking sides so I’ll happily step aside and let another firm take over negotiations. Larger firms can attempt some sort of Chinese wall arrangements but in my experience they’re not very effective and it’s hard to police them over time.

Thanks @Gaucho , that’s a very reasonable concern.  In the immediate term, I’ve run a preliminary conflicts check (there are no directly adverse matters), and, should I be selected, I will be disclosing the position to my firm’s Fiduciary Review Board so that another conflicts check can be run, and the firm will be aware of the position going forward.  We do take conflicts seriously, and where appropriate, set up ethical walls.  These measures are important, but not arduous; on average I get a few notices a month that I’m walled off from certain matters, or certain attorneys are walled off from matters I’m working on.  This frequently comes up when an attorney from another firm laterals in. Were a conflict to come up, I would also anticipate that it would be on a fairly discrete matter, e.g., a trademark interference proceeding.  Were this to happen, despite being walled off on the side of my firm, I would consult with the other Dai Foundation board members and likely wall myself off on the Foundation side just to be safe.  I anticipate there will be a lot of projects I can do good work on, and shifting one or two assignments around should not materially affect the value I can add. While I cannot make sweeping representations for the firm, I would personally be very surprised if Morgan Lewis took on a position as  customer/consumer class counsel in the sort of nascent litigation we have seen in the DAO/DeFi space.  Likewise for IP, if you look at statistics on Docket Navigator, you will see that about 75% of our district court patent litigation is as counsel for defendants, and it is uncommon for us to represent nonpracticing entities. If Morgan Lewis were involved in a major matter directly against Maker or the Dai Foundation, I would consult with the other Foundation board members, and respect any decision they reach on continued board membership.  But again, my sincere hope and belief is that any conflicts that arise would be minor and resolvable. Lastly, I would stress that I am running for this position in my personal capacity, and this would not create any attorney-client relationship with me or Morgan Lewis.

Lawyers mean regulators and courts come knocking…particularly if a delegate is counsel at a law firm doing work in securities litigation or broker/dealer regulation. Maker has positioned itself to operate beyond the reach of any regulator or any court … I fear that a lawyer may be looking to “prove his-her worth” by dragging us into something.

smartcontracts:  beyond the reach of any regulator or any court … I fear that a lawyer may be looking to “prove his-her worth” by dragging us into something.   There is a legitimate question as to whether specific candidates could increase the risk of regulatory scrutiny although I’m not sure why you think lawyers are a special case. The risk of regulatory scrutiny might increase if the candidate was implicated in financial or other serious crime that adversely affected the Foundation. The good news is that the Dai Foundation has very strict rules requiring board members to act ethically and with integrity. Regarding litigation, I’m a commercial lawyer so I don’t see any point in launching litigation for the fun of it. Most of my career has been spent resolving conflicts through negotiation and quiet settlement. This is actually how most commercial disagreements are solved. It’s just that the outside world doesn’t see any of that. That said, if the interests of the Foundation were legally threatened in any way, the board should be allowed to take all reasonable, lawful steps to protect those interests. We operate in a litigious, competitive landscape so that only seems fair. As to why a lawyer like myself might be a good fit, one of the specific objectives of the Foundation is the protection of MakerDAO’s intellectual property. This core objective is one of the reasons I’m nominating for the role - I have over 20 years of working with intellectual property and I know that I can make a meaningful contribution to the Dai Foundation’s work.

Apology for the late comments. We have voted “Neither candidates” as we believe there should be more time to assess both candidates. The fault is of course on us as well. But from the comments by both candidates on various posts on the Maker forum, we believe both have passion and insights for the protocol. But question for @Daimon-Law . His introduction doesn’t mention anything about how he’s deeply involved with Avalanche ecosystem. According to the Linkedin, he’s director at Aventures DAO, which is “a unique Venture Capital fund comprised of OG Avalanche community members whose goal is to support developing technologies in the digital asset space” and he’s also Director and Chief Legal Officer at Pangolin Exchange, which is “a multichain decentralized cryptocurrency exchange (DEX) on the Avalanche and Songbird Networks.”  image797×851 56.2 KB  Can you clarify whether you are helping them as client relationship or are involved in as a team? CLO and Director role seem like more than just “help guide projects across the industry.”

Thank you for the questions and the feedback about voting process. I wish I could help with the internal process but it’s a busy time of the year for MakerDAO so I understand that this hasn’t gone exactly as planned. An AMA  is still in the works and I’m keen to meet everyone on a call and take questions that way. To the specifics: Pangolin and AVentures DAO were clients but my involvement with both has dropped off significantly since February. AVenturesDAO has a strong game-fi/NFT focus and they are a very small syndicate built around a core of Web3 enthusiasts who do it in their spare time. The syndicate was based on the MolochDAO model and I’m really proud of the work we’ve done: strong values of supporting teams by providing access to members of the fund who work in Web3. I learnt a lot. Keep in mind that I’ve been in the technology sector since 1997 and heavily involved in crypto since 2017. I’ve made public contributions to Hyperledger, Sushiswap, Polkadot, Kali, Curia, Edgeware DAO, Flare, Codius, LexDAO, LobsterDAO and many other projects. My interests are fairly broad as you will see from my github page: Daimon-Law (Paul-IMC) · GitHub, none of which involve Avalanche projects or even investments. Like a lot of passionate Web3 lawyers, we do a lot of work without much fanfare, largely for free. I’ve worked with NTT and IBM as well and they have huge blockchain teams/investments that none of us will ever truly know about except through their patent applications (which are worth looking into as they reveal a very different story about blockchain tech and Web3 than that presented in the media or even amongst ourselves here). I don’t see that as an impediment - to me, having a broad experience across a wide range of Web2 as well as Web3 projects, networks and dApps is core to what I believe in. What’s more important for the Dai Foundation role is that (1) I avoid all conflicts of interest with the Dai Foundation and MakerDAO (2) I’m aligned with the values of the Dai Foundation and (3) I have the technical expertise to assist the Board in fulfilling its goals. @Doo_StableLab - I hope I’ve answered your questions and happy to take any follow-ups you have.

Thank you very much to both @Daimon-Law and @0xbocaJ for stepping forward to be part of this election poll. Congratulations to @Daimon-Law for being nominated to the Dai Foundation Board by the MKR Voters. The Dai Foundation Board will now process this nomination.

I’m very honoured. If I could thank a few people before I take my first steps in the role… Firstly - thank you to @0xbocaJ for nominating and his kind words to me yesterday as the voting closed. I know that we’ll be seeing more of your perceptive contributions over the coming months and years and I hope to meet you soon. I also wanted to thank all the Delegates and others who entrusted me with their vote. I’ll do my best to live up to the high standards set by you all. Finally to @sorenpeter and the Board - I really appreciate the efforts required to open a position to work alongside you. I can’t wait to meet everyone and get to work! I hope you all have a safe and happy holiday season and successful 2023. Thanks again.
This topic was automatically closed after 90 days. New replies are no longer allowed.
